headline: Graduate Reseach and Teaching Assistant at The University of Kansas School of Business
about: I am interested in the analysis, modeling, and optimization of complex systems through the use of operations research methods. In this regard, I particularly worked on problems with vehicle routing nature, namely, Helicopter Routing Problem and consolidation of milk-run logistics. In one project, the problem was to route a helicopter that transports crew members to and from offshore gas platforms, where weight and passenger capacity, and flight time constraints must be taken into account. In another project, the problem was to design an optimal logistics network for a branch of the largest Iranian automaker. The problem was to route various types of vehicles to pick up and deliver pallets of products in a network consisting of supplier and assembly plant nodes. I also collaborated in a project aimed at the joint determination of the optimal asset procurement method and its maintenance schedule. The objectives to be optimized are total cost, reliability, and availability. I also worked in the project for optimization of spare parts management at the National Iranian Copper Industries Co. (NICICO). My responsibilities include analyzing and optimizing spare parts inventory level, developing a software tool for forecasting spare parts demand, and analyzing and optimizing the process of spare parts management system.
school: The University of Kansas School of Business

headline: Research Engineer at South 8 Technologies
about:
Even after 3 years of researching and engineering batteries I still find them almost magical. They are essentially nanoscale sponges absorbing practically invisible lithium-ions at the thermodynamic and kinetic limits of the liquid soup of electrolyte transporting them and continue to excite both me for the science and an insanely rapid growing market for their capabilities and hope of a greener future.

In my current role as a Research Engineer, I get to directly study that magic by researching and developing South 8 Technologies' novel liquefied gas (LiGas) electrolyte ranging from testing various electrolyte formulations/additives to optimizing for specific electrodes or use cases. Concurrently, I help train and educate Research Associates on cell construction and electrochemistry fundamentals, as well as direct cell builds for various projects. I have experience using and interpreting data from cyclic voltametry (CV), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), conductivity measurements and general battery cycling (life cycle, rate and temperature capabilities) on Biologic and Maccor cyclers.

I've also had experience conducting UL safety testing, including thermal runaway, temperature, short circuit and overcharge/discharge testing of both modules and packs used in electric vehicles during my time at Flux Power. During my graduate studies, I also extensively studied lithium metal anodes, first authoring a paper on optical in-situ characterization of lithium plating and stripping, took multiple courses on electrochemistry and materials at UC San Diego and established and effectively managed a battery lab at SDSU.

My background in Mechanical Engineering has also provided a unique ability to critically solve problems through engineering and building practical solutions that are not always available commercially.

As I continue to grow in my career, I hope to keep learning about the world of electrochemical devices, research and develop interesting new technologies, educate and lead the next generation of innovators and researchers and ultimately help contribute to a greener and cleaner future for us all.
school: San Diego State University-California State University

headline: Complaining about a problem without proposing a solutions is called whining.
Strategic Partnership Focused | Sales Engineer | Voice of the Customer
about:
Aaron Scott is an entrepreneur, a sales specialist, a strategist, and a leader. He is driven to create and work on projects that reflect the world in which he wants to live.  This drove him and his co-founder to create SewnStone an inflatable concrete technology that was recently granted 10 US Patents and PCT. 

He led the Sales Team at Go Moment (a Google backed artificial intelligence company who automates facets of guest service at hotels) accounting for over 68% of new revenue.  He acquired and maintained 7 out of the top 10 accounts.  He did so creating sales tools (such as ROI calculators used in customer facing presentations) and setup strategic partnerships.  Aaron has demonstrated this sales acumen in several different industries.

As a consultant Aaron successfully augmented capital raises for Metamason, Virtual Sonic (Joint Venture created www.rolandcloud.com), Go Moment, Shell Shock, Sterilis Medical, amongst others.  He went on to serve as an advisor to some of these companies and has invested both his time and personal capital.  He has re-structured companies such as Distinct Management: restaffing, refocusing marketing efforts, digitizing business operations, rewriting renting standards, and managing the staff. 

Aaron began his professional career at the CardioPulmonary Research Institute in New York.  He assisted as a labtech and intern studying Non-Apoptotic Cell Death from elevated levels of oxygen radicals through elevated gaseous O2 concentration.  Later exploring kinase pathway activation/inhibition of NF-kB in lung epithelial cells from elevated O2 environments (simulating Oxygen environments of premature babies).  

Realizing, laboratory work was not his calling he moved on to an opportunity at Smith Barney Citigroup.  He work as an intern, winning the intern stock game twice.  He was later hired on to run new client acquisition evolving to statistical analysis and quantitative modeling.  

Aaron is currently consulting and looking for his next full-time project.

headline: Senior Managing Director at Houlihan Lokey
about:
Mr. Miller was a member of Houlihan Lokey‚Äôs Board of Directors prior to the firm‚Äôs IPO in August 2015. With more than two decades of experience at the firm, he has designed, implemented, and managed some of Houlihan Lokey‚Äôs key strategic initiatives, including the firm‚Äôs entry into distressed M&A, capital markets, and management consulting.

On behalf of his clients, Mr. Miller has executed hundreds of mergers and acquisitions and financing transactions in a multitude of industries, including some of the most notable transactions in the firm‚Äôs history. He founded Houlihan Lokey‚Äôs Special Situations practice. He founded the American Bankruptcy Institute‚Äôs Committee on Investment Banking and Corporate Finance and has headed the Committee‚Äôs annual Dealmakers‚Äô Conference. He has been ranked by The Deal as one of the most active special situation investment bankers, and he was the youngest person named to the Los Angeles Business Journal‚Äôs Who‚Äôs Who of Banking & Finance Turnaround Specialists.

Mr. Miller is a respected public speaker and lectures at top law and business schools across the nation. He has also written two books‚ÄîBuying and Selling the Distressed Company and Advising the Distressed Company‚Äîwhich have been used to educate many of the industry‚Äôs key participants. 

In 2014, Mr. Miller architected and managed the launch of Houlihan Lokey‚Äôs Strategic Consulting business through the acquisition of Bridge Strategy Group, making Houlihan Lokey the first global investment bank to offer premium management consulting services to its clients.

Before joining Houlihan Lokey, Mr. Miller was a Management Consultant with Bain & Co.

headline: Network Support Specialist at US Navy
about:
Hello potential boss!
I'll "BLUF" (Bottom line up front) this by saying openly that I have ADHD, so my apologies for the tangential, wordy mess that will be most of what you read here.

I was born May 21st, 1992 in Richfield, Utah to my father Bret Baum and my mother Laurie Mitchell. I have two siblings, both sisters born June 19th, 1990 and September 6th, 1993. Raised within 30 miles of my hometown. Absolutely enjoyed/excelled at math (geometry, trig, algebra, calculus) and physics growing up. Would love to eventually go to college to get a degree in astrophysics, quantum mechanics, add infinitum. 

I love learning new information about almost anything and am a wealth of random knowledge, but my favorites are physics/software technology, the world, universe. I love learning how everything works down to a base/component level and almost whenever posed with a question about any of the above, I will try to find the answer by any means (books, YouTube, Google etc). If I need to know something to complete a task and don't, or just want to know more information, Google or YouTube. If I believe it to possibly be in the public domain and I don't know how something works or how to do something, I will without shame open Google and search until I find it, or sufficient searches have been done to show it is not easily obtainable through those channels in which case I will turn to a supervisor. Some would tell me to do that first, but supervisors have their own jobs and I feel it unfair to bother them with a question at my level if I couldn't be bothered to do the initial search for the answer myself. All that being said I don't believe everything I see or hear and will frequently try to find multiple sources dictating the same info before stating it with confidence. 

Mental Health issues may take my mind off track every once in a while but if I hyper-focus on a task, and am given the breathing space to execute, I will perform on average better than my peers. Some of my strengths would be attentiveness to detail, my adaptation to change, and my adequate timeliness on competing tasks. I'm usually in the top 2-3 performers when viewing technical job performance (servers, printers, workstations, switches/routers, basic IT/work related knowledge etc). My weaknesses would be effective direct (face to face) communication as I usually need to preface conversations before I have them, my inability to accept change for the sake of change, and my work-arrival timeliness as some of my health conditions make my sleep patterns variable, especially when on regular shifts.

headline: SWE Intern @ Argo AI
about:
Short version: I study computer science because I‚Äôve always enjoyed puzzles and logic, which implies that pursuing CS will lead to a life of enjoyment. I haven't rigorously and mathematically proved that statement, but to put it bluntly, "it's cool as heck!"

Here are my projects: https://ctwobosius.github.io/TheWongFireside/projects.html

I've done some cool things with Argo AI, automating tasks and developing GPU libraries, and with Breakout mentors, where I taught game development.


The story:

For 18 years, I wandered through school without direction, able to find my way through the maze, traversing through writing, art, math, animation, economics, law, history, mechanical drafting, martial arts, but never able to piece together why I wandered the maze, how the paths and experiences all connected together. 

It wasn't until I stumbled across a Python YouTube tutorial that I was launched into the exciting world of computer science - where math, English, everything began fitting together - culminating into a skill that shapes the very future of this Earth on a scale that is ever increasing as technology progresses. 

As I dove deeper into computer science, I found myself with a tool able to turn thoughts into reality, the vast, complicated world into understandable models - from Python to C++, HTML to SQL, the possibilities were limitless. This discovery opened up my dream to become that "YouTube tutorial," that inspiration which replaces goalless meandering with fruitful purpose. Whether that is achieved by developing technology that solves today's problems, or empowering others to do the same, I hope my work betters myself and others, paving a path to a brighter future.

headline: M.S. Levy Economics Institute | uOttawa Alumni
about:
Data-driven professional committed to increase efficiency by setting up innovative processes that leads to a team‚Äôs success, identifying blind spots and finding simplified solutions to unforeseen problems. I am firm believer in the transformative power of creativity and storytelling as a way to propel teams to success.

At the University of Ottawa, I learnt from experienced professionals about issues in Political Science, Sociology, and Statistics. I polished my presentation and public speaking skills by being part of clubs such as the Model United Nations, and attended the House of Commons at the Canadian Parliament to deliver a speech on policy-making. Taking courses in business management and financial accounting helped me sharpen my skills in financial modeling. Besides that, as part of the editing team of the Undergraduate Journal of Politics, Policy and Society (UJPPS), I had the privilege to serve as an editor for an outstanding academic journal.

I work best in creative spaces that foster innovation. For instance, at the Levy Economics Institute, we build strong cross-functional project squads and learn quickly by empirically testing research ideas. At this think tank, I had the fantastic opportunity to work with professionals analyzing trends in poverty and inequality, which taught me how to connect data analysis insights with real-life applications. Several of the projects we worked on required a lot of accuracy in its execution and to acquire a great level of attention to detail.  I honed my skills in data visualization and interpreting models in a critical way. These skills are highly transferable to fields such as finance, business management, technology, among others. 

I have worked with SMEs in the arrangements for expansion plans, including the process of incorporating a company in foreign jurisdictions, from crafting shareholder agreements to implementing the most tax efficient structure. Besides that, I was able to provide to my clients a reduction of ~3% in the cost of raw material by auditing supplier agreements. Furthermore, I Implemented and streamlined data management procedures, improving operational efficiency by 8%.

My five-year plan includes gaining expertise in valuation of assets and sourcing of investment opportunities. I also write several articles on matters related to finance, technology, and innovation, which you can find in the link in my profile.

headline: Chemistry | Inorganic | Organic | Polymer Science | Electrochemistry
about:
I was drawn towards science since my childhood. I did my high school studies in the biological science stream and followed chemistry, biology, and physics. Based on the results of a very competitive examination held by the Department of Examinations, Sri Lanka, I was selected to pursue a bachelor‚Äôs degree course in Applied Sciences at the University of Sri Jayewardenepura. I studied Chemistry, Polymer Science & Technology and Physics as principle subjects. In the chemistry special program, I had the opportunity to broaden my knowledge in all branches of undergraduate chemistry, which reinforced and solidified my intense interest in chemistry.

I also had the opportunity to complete an industrial training project as a chemist in training at Raigam Marketing Services (Pvt) Ltd, Sri Lanka. That training program gave me a lot of exposure to industrial chemistry while allowing me to further enhance my interpersonal skills.

Currently, I am pursuing my graduate studies at Wayne State University, and working under the supervision of Dr. C. N. Verani. I have been working on two projects; One project is developing nanoscale rectification devices using first row transition metal complexes and the other project is based on developing Langmuir-Blodgett films for corrosion inhibition. My research on different fields has afforded me proficiency in electrochemistry, organic synthesis, LB surface deposition, in addition to an array of characterization techniques including NMR, FTIR, HPLC, LCMS, GC, SEM, UV-vis, CV, Tafel, EIS.

I have always enjoyed teaching, and as a teaching assistant and instructor, I am in the process of enhancing my interpersonal skills in guiding, directing, assisting, and teaching students.

headline: Security Executive & Advisor | Government & Commercial Sector Expert | White House Presidential Innovation Fellow
about:
As a security executive with more than 20 years in compliance and security policy, I bring a unique combination of experiences in government and commercial sectors.  With this dual-sided view, I help both start-up and larger companies work effectively with the government, build proper organizational structure, achieve security clearance, and anticipate future hurdles. On the other side, government partners trust my ability to recognize their uniquely positioned issues and take the lead in devising and executing complex strategy, so they can focus on the daily tactics of their critical roles.

My collaboration approach includes finding connection points with team members and customers across all levels and functions to build rapport, earn trust, and gain an intimate understanding of an organization through the eyes of its people. I take this macro level approach to identify what a business/institution is dealing with and how that plays into the larger picture of its mission, so I can deliver specialized knowledge and open new perspectives around government and security topics.  

From working with cross-cultural teams to understanding the geopolitical climate of various regions, the work I do is inherently global in nature and I believe joining forces with people of varying backgrounds, viewpoints, and areas of expertise is a catalyst to real game-changing innovation and impact.  

I consider my recent selection as a Class of 2021 Presidential Innovation Fellow the culmination of my career success. As an ‚Äúentrepreneur in residence‚Äù for one year, I was chosen for executive-level expertise, innovation, influence, and problem-solving dexterity. headline: Engineer I at Seagate Technology
about:
Worked on numerous Engineering teams with various projects with topics in computer hardware device development though VHDL. Device Firmware development though C. Information processing though java using various computer science algorithms. Electrical engineering fundamentals. 
 
Developed a interest in computer hardware and the architecture behind this hardware though school. 

Favorite school project: MIPS Processor
One of my favorite projects in school was when I was tasked with building a MIPS processor from the ground up using logic design coupled with VHDL and Verilog. The processor was able to ability to properly execute assembly code and was also fully pipelined to allow for processing of five instructions at a time. I also worked with forwarding information within the pipeline itself to boost processor performance by shortening instruction processing time that use the processors critical path. This project was done though ModelSim which not only allowed for simulation of these hardware description languages, but also enabled me to write test benches for various different components and verify their logic. This project has influenced my recent interest to build a RISC-V processor using the same VHDL and Verilog methods.

headline: Principal System Engineer at Raytheon
about:
A. Dean Chacon, PhD has used his background in physics, mathematics, and computer programming to model complex systems (such as spacecraft imaging systems) to determine and optimize their performance, and has designed systems to meet challenging state-of-the-art requirements.

He has performed requirement decompositions to allocate requirements from systems to sub-systems and then debugged the resulting system when the sub-systems are integrated and tested, working alongside the sub-system engineers.

Specialties:
Integrating multiple sub-system technologies into a working system
Matlab, Python, C, C++, Ada, Assembler, and FORTRAN programming languages.

Modeling complex systems to estimate performance and determine the performance-driving parameters, reducing cost and risk.

Statistical methods of measuring random processes (such as imaging device pointing error) to determine the significance of the measured results, and using these methods with the Monte Carlo technique.

Using Kalman filtering and quaternions to solve attitude estimation problems.

Using Microsoft Office products to present his results to his company's customers.

Where he has used these specialties:

System Engineering of earth-observing geostationary satellites and polar orbiting satellites:
Weather satellites GOES-IJK/LM, GOES-R, and WSFA.

Simulation of radio signal propagation to and from a satellite starting with signal generation going all the way to signal detection in a spectrum analyzer.

Simulations of Space Systems/Loral spacecraft.  Debugging the Factory Acceptance Test procedure for the SS/L's Maneuver Planning Software (known as "APS").

System Engineering for MTSAT-1R to determine the imaging device's line of slight jitter.

Programming spacecraft simulations of the MTSAT-1R weather satellite imager payload.

Programming simulations of the performance of the SBIRS Payload Attitude Reference System.

Location:
San Jose, CA.  Willing to relocate

headline: Private label skin care company that is Dermatologist based and manufactured in the USA. Formulation to distribution.
about:
For over 40 years my family has been in the Skin Care business. We have been making private label skin care products that you can find in some of the largest retailers in the USA. Dermatologist Formulated products are our specialty.

We are an ISO certified lab and can do OTC products such as SPF and Acne treatment topicals. 

PL Skin Solutions creates additional products with an emphasis on CBD. Our CBD comes from a GMP certified facility. 

We can make a product, branded with your chosen name, that is similar to one of our current formulas that we manufacture  or we can design something completely different. To accomplish this, we have developed the following turn-key process for creating products:

Conceptualization of product line- we work with you to figure out the best approach and configuration of your product offering, what should be in the line, not and etc.

Dermatologist formulated - our dermatologists work with our team of chemists to create the perfect formula for your line and test it in our offices. They will continually keep you abreast of new trends in the industry and tell you when an ingredient change is in order or needed.

Packaging, design - we work with you to find the right bottles, pumps, boxes to deliver the product and help you with label design. We source all the components through our trusted primary suppliers.

Manufacturing - we provide all necessary stages (mixing, filling capping, coding, labeling, packaging, shipping, etc.)

Logistics - we store all of our raw & finished goods at our warehouse and ship throughout the entire USA.

Let's connect and disccus how we can work together and make sure your real estate needs are met!

headline: Portfolio Manager | Senior Vice President - Wealth Management at UBS Financial Services Inc.
about:
Office: 937-226-6583

"Our practice is unique. We're not a typical financial advisory practice. Our proprietary valuation process helps us manage several distinct investment portfolios. As the portfolio manager, we practice the time honored tradition of valuing and selecting investments one security at a time, managing risk, and constructing portfolios to meet client objectives. We do not subcontract portfolio management out to mutual funds or other people. The end result and goal is that our clients save on fees and enjoy better returns in the process." ‚Äì Aaron S. Campbell, Portfolio Manager & First Vice President ‚Äì Wealth Management

Passionate about delivering quality advice, Aaron has earned the Certified Financial Planner‚Ñ¢ (CFP¬Æ) certification ‚Äì the industry standard of excellence for financial planning. In addition to managing investment portfolios, his group focuses on full financial planning - assessing such issues as client income needs, taxes, titling, insurance, gifting, trusts, and all manner of unique family and business situations. 

Aaron holds FINRA Series 7 and Series 66 securities licenses, a National Futures Association (NFA) Series 31 license, as well as several state Accident and Health, Life, and Variable Annuity licenses.

Aaron earned his B.A. in philosophy from the University of Utah and has post-graduate certifications from NYU in valuation and corporate finance. He is a student of investment valuation techniques. Aaron lives in Springboro with his two teenage sons.

PhD Student at Texas Tech University
about:
Aaron Carman is an Electrical Engineering graduate student at Texas Tech University. He is currently pursuing a Ph.D. at Texas Tech, with a focus on microwave radar technologies. He has over 4 years of experience as a research assistant in the RF and Analog Research Lab and the Center for Nanophotonics.

Previously, Aaron was the President of the Gamma Nu chapter of Eta Kappa Nu. Before focusing solely on Eta Kappa Nu, he was also the chapter's Initiate Coordinator and the IEEE Student Branch's Digital Kits Coordinator.

Before beginning his job as an undergraduate research assistant, Aaron tutored Freshman level classes in the Electrical Engineering department. He assisted students with their understanding of Modern Digital Systems, and organized tutoring sessions to prepare for exams.

Aaron's technical skills include:
Circuit Design and Simulation (EagleCAD, LTSpice, AWR)
Multiphysics Simulation (COMSOL)
Programming (C/C++, Python, Verilog, MATLAB)
SMD Soldering (0402 minimum)
Experimentation and Testing (Oscilloscope, Multimeter, Spectrum Analyzer)

Aaron's research interests include RF and radar systems, biomedical radar applications, RF IC design, and antenna design.

In addition to Aaron's technical skills, he also possesses numerous leadership skills such as interpersonal communication, organization, delegation, and a willingness to take charge.

headline: Senior Software Engineer
about:
I'm a full stack developer experienced in all aspects of application development, be it implementing front end designs into functional interfaces to back-end services implemented in both Java and Go and sometimes Node.js. The majority of my work has been done in Java, utilizing Spring to implement micro-services or software as a service patterns, and I've started utilizing Go for greenfield projects. I have experience building mobile applications, mostly developing back-end services for the projects like the Sprint Football Live (NFL) app, NASCAR Sprint Cup Mobile app and the NBA 2 Go app. I've also developed privacy preserving authentication/authorization applications where I created a SAML Identity Provider (IDP) which was used by customers to quickly integrate their systems with our "Trust Network" A&A app, while also implementing diverse authentication technologies from Facial recognition (utilizing ShuftiPro) to WebAuthn or U2F, and many, many more. I'm more productive as a back-end developer because of my mediocre graphic design skills but if there are design specs available I can turn them into functioning user interfaces. I enjoy working at the front end every bit as much as I enjoy server side work, but for me front end work is a highly iterative process, and that can be timely.

Technologies: Java, Go, Node.js, JavaScript, Maven, Spring, grails, groovy, JPA, Hibernate, MySql, Oracle, mongoDB, Micro-services, Docker, Tomcat, Weblogic, JSON, JSON-LD, XML, XSD, JUnit, Selenium, Mockito, SAML, OIDC, XACML, jQuery, Bootstrap, Git, JIRA, U2F, Webauthn

headline: PhD Student in Computational Science & Engineering and Mechanical Engineering
about: I am a PhD student at MIT studying computational science and engineering in the mechanical engineering department. I work on state-of-the-art numerical techniques to solve computationally intensive problems. In other words, I create fast and accurate algorithms to solve really big problems! As an undergraduate, I studied applied mathematics and electrical engineering  at Brown University.  My interests include Bayesian inverse problems, reduced-order modeling, uncertainty quantification, stochastic differential equations, digital signal processing, and wave phenomena (e.g. acoustics and optics).  One particularly interesting application of my work is seabed imaging! In the past, I have explored blind and semi-blind source separation algorithms applied to musical signals for use in real-time visualizations. I also worked in an optics lab studying fundamental devices for use in terahertz technologies.

headline: Staff Control Systems Engineer at Energy Transfer
about:
Currently, I support and maintain the DeltaV control system of an NGL storage facility and terminal, and crude terminal, having completed a full DCS upgrade from PlantPAx to DeltaV Live in 2020.

Other specialties are PLC programming of Allen Bradley systems (RSLogix and Connected Components Workbench), and HMI design in FactoryTalk View Studio (PlantPAx) and Wonderware. I'm also proficient in AutoCAD.

Previous project experience includes 5 years of commissioning local control systems for a major oil pipeline in Russia. I saw it through every stage from design to start-up including generation of technical specifications, FAT, and SAT procedures; development and testing of upgraded ControlLogix PLC programs, and turnover. The scope included upgrading systems at existing pump stations, new pump stations, tank farm, and single-point-mooring terminal facility.

I have also spent time programming, creating HMIs, commissioning, and troubleshooting at new facilities for refining and underground storage.

headline: Graduate Student in Theology at Seattle Pacific University and Barista at Ascension
about:
It wasn't until I stood barefoot (one cheap flip-flop down) with bags of groceries on the dirty streets of New York that I realized how much I treasured the home I had left.  

I grew up in a Korean-American household in Texas, and I am still continuing to realize what an amazing home my mom has crafted.  I loved watching and helping my mom in the kitchen, and now, that curiosity has developed into a professional interest in the intersection of food, writing, and design.

From planning retreats for 30 guys to keeping the $40,000 budget for my debate team's travel in the green, college has given me great opportunities to learn how to delegate tasks and support team members.  My humanities degree has guided me in learning to critically assess sources, conduct thorough research, and write in a range of styles.  Along the way, protecting the space to eat and play board games with friends has kept me grounded and revealed how much I value the connecting power of food.

In internships, I have edited website pages and content in WordPress, designed social media ad campaigns, and taught English classes to over 20 Czech youth.  I am looking forward to continue sharpening punchy writing and cultivating an eye for smart design, and I am thankful for the home that has brought me here.

If you need a cooking partner, flexible writer, or careful eye that cares about the little things, please reach out; I would love to hear about you and your home.

My interests led me to pursue degrees from Humboldt State University and California State University, Sacramento where I completed both Bachelor and Master of Science Degrees focusing primarily on user trends and resource management  (i.e. social science). I spent my college summers working for California Department of Parks and Recreation working as a Park Aide. I later attained an internship working for the U.S. Department of Interior, Bureau of Land Management, California State Office as an Assistant Youth Coordinator. Most recently, I landed a permanent appointment with the U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Pacific Southwest Regional Office where I work as a Volunteers and Service Program Specialist. I am currently working on developing my professional portfolio with the intent of becoming a program manager  for the Forest Service.

headline: Lithography for HVM | Physical Chemist Ph.D. UCSB
about:
Have you ever been unable to choose between two conflicting interests? My academic interest can be understood through a drive to bridge science and physical, cultural history as a scientist whose interests are driven by a strong background in archiving and anthropology. As a Ph.D. student in physical chemistry at UC Santa Barbara, I am using the research field of gas phase spectroscopy and mass spectrometry to investigate cultural questions such as 'What did the ancient Mayans drink?" and "What does that knowledge tell me about their culture?" Using modern analysis techniques with low limits of detection and high sensitivity, we are able to quantify drink residues in pottery fragments from the Mayan era in order to understand the class stratification and diverse trade networks.

Fields like anthropology or archeology often seek to understand the multifaceted complexities of defining and understanding a community through the analysis of personal experience, observation, written record, and conversation. Scientific tools and approaches often can support these narratives and expedite our narrative construction. I believe that scientific methods can serve as better tools to illuminate history and aid minority and disadvantaged groups commonly neglected in society‚Äôs narratives. 

The collaboration of analytical scientific techniques with experts in the fields of art and archeology to dictate the effect of these findings on cultural narratives, is the focus of my Ph.D. and hopefully of my larger career.

headline: Researcher in Nanomaterials | Aspiring Neuroscientist
about: My research developing synthetic strategies for enhancing the optical properties of narrow-gap semiconductor nanocrystals. Advances in my research helps in development of infrared LEDs and infrared detectors with enhanced performance. Research in this field is interdisciplinary, and involves bringing together skills from chemistry, physics, material science, making use of both experimental and theoretical methods. Apart from synthesis and spectroscopic characterization, I have learnt to use electronics and machining skills to design and modify spectroscopic instruments to suit our needs. I also work on developing theoretical models for making predictions and explaining our experimental observations.

For the past 3 years, I have managed the implementation of information management systems at the facilities of PJSC Gazprom. Within the framework of the projects, my team completed 100% of the tasks on time.

I use my knowledge and experience to:
- increase the reliability of equipment;
- assessment of the technical condition of the equipment;

headline: Military Veteran ~ Project/Program Manager II ~ PMP certification in progress.
about:
As a Program Manager/Project Manager, I work intimately within the engineering ops group. My current position requires meticulous record keeping, creative & flexible problem solving, exemplary written & verbal communication skills, and the ability to provide direction & vision throughout the project lifecycle. I manage high-level attributes; scope, timeline, budget, resource allocation, client relationship, reporting & overall project success for a portfolio of projects. In addition to supporting the client directly, IMCORP also provide technical assistance & general trouble shooting; as well as oversight & specialized reporting that aid our clients with their power-line cable reliability efforts.

IMCORP is a leading provider of power cable reliability assessment services for medium & high voltage (5kV to 500kV) power cable systems in the Utility/Solar/Wind sector. Clients include electric utility companies & renewable sites (wind & solar farms); as well as major airports, sports arenas & various other commercial/industrial platforms; New & existing/retrofit installations. 

I provide a single point of contact from initial contract stages (PM team/Sales/Contracts/ Eng. Ops/Fleet), through its final stages of completion (Accounting/Ops); spearheading all required tasks & funneling department inquiries as required.

During the last 15 years of my professional experience Ive continued to be self-motivated & dedicated to my craft; leveraging an accomplished and varied background in project management, engineering/warehouse/pharmacy ops management, logistics, customer service and practical engineering experience to consistently exceed expectations for a multitude of roles. I truly enjoy interacting with my peers and customers alike and seeing a project through its complete lifecycle; which leads me to consider growing into another role, and/or pursuing a more challenging and collaborative role within a company that values energetic, accountable and competent leadership. Performing my job well is important to me. PMP certification is in progress as I further my learning. 

About me: I enjoy mountain biking, riding ATV's & being outdoors when able. I work at keeping up to date with new and exciting technology & I enjoy seeing whats going on in the world we live in. Ive recently finished the creation of a local dog park and it is now up and running after 4 years of working with local businesses/neighborhoods and the city mayor/appointed personnel. Finally, I look forward to spending as much time as I can with my family and friends.

In my career, over 12 years, I gained strong technical knowledge and experience in solving difficult and complex engineering tasks from automotive, solar and safety-related systems industry. Through my creativity, not only once I pioneered new trends, technologies and improvements in my work.

I enjoy designing power converters (DC/DC, DC/AC and AC/DC), analog, digital and mixed signal control systems,  complex printed circuit board (PCB) designs, defining innovative architectures for electronic systems, generating engineering documentation, integration, bringing up electronics to life and development from concept to production in accordance to regulations.

My experience cover designs using multiprocessor systems based on DSP, CPU, MCU or PLD (FPGA and CPLD) in real-time applications and using new technologies for power conversion such as wide band gap devices GaN and SiC.

I have hands on experience with noise suppression techniques, EMI/ESD immunity control during the product design and EMI mitigation.

I'm proficient in leading teams, project planning and task management. Engineer able to operate autonomously and following development processes and best practices. I tested my leadership skills when I headed a team of 9 engineers and coached, trained less experienced engineers. I collaborated with many great engineers from software, controls and mechanical departments and also with HR while I facilitated hiring electrical engineers.

I'm seeking new opportunities to grow as an electrical engineer and use my deep knowledge in countless of challenging applications to broaden my experience. 

My skills include:
Design: DC/DC, DC/AC and AC/DC power conversion, A/D mixed signal control systems, schematic capture, PCB design, simulations, various analysis, EMI/EMC/ESD control and mitigation

headline: NOMA, NCARB, AIA, EcoDistricts AP
about: A.L. Hu, AIA, NOMA, EcoDistricts AP, is a queer, nonbinary transgender Taiwanese-American organizer, facilitator, and Registered Architect who lives and works in New York City. Their practice synthesizes organizing for racial, class, and gender justice with design; rethinks the architect‚Äôs role in facilitating accessible spaces; and manifests in design, visual media, and collaborative cultural work. They are a 2019-2021 Enterprise Rose Architectural Fellow. They are a member of as well as a conduit connecting many organizations, including Design as Protest, Dark Matter University, NCARB, and AIA New York. A.L. writes the not-so-regular Queer Agenda newsletter, and provides brainpower and energy for Queeries, an ongoing survey and community-building project for and by LGBTQIA+ architects and designers. They received a Master of Architecture from Columbia University GSAPP.

headline: Director, Institute for Diversity in the Arts at Stanford University
about:
Organizational Strategist  *  Creative Lead *  Racial Justice Educator 

A-lan A. Holt is the youngest director in the arts at Stanford University. There she leads the Institute for Diversity in the Arts (IDA), a popular university-facing program housed in the Office of the Vice President for the Arts. IDA is a home for Stanford‚Äôs diverse communities and has been particularly successful in supporting underrepresented students and communities on and off-campus. At Stanford she teaches (as an appointed member of Academic Council), initiates strategy and programming in the areas of diversity, equity and culture; and supports campus-wide leadership and initiatives toward inclusivity and anti-racism. Holt leverages over ten years experience building inclusive belonging and stewarding organizational change. 

A-lan is a practicing multi-disciplinary artist whose work has been recognized in theater, poetry, and film. In 2018 she was a Sundance Film Fellow, a SFFilm Screenwriting Fellow, and is a frequent contributor on-air at KQED Arts (the Bay Areas NPR). Her debut film Inamorata was acquired by Issa Rae Productions and won a special jury prize for best first-time filmmaker at San Francisco‚Äôs Black Film Festival. She is the host of "Every Skin Has a Story: Creatives of Color Take on Beauty" presented by science skincare line Retrouve, and is often a lead creative on film projects for commercial branding. In 2016 her debut artist book Moonwork was published by Candor Arts Chicago, shorted-listed for the Cornish Family Prize and acquired by several public and private institutions globally.
job_title: Director, Institute for Diversity in the Arts

headline: Design Daredevil, Content Creator, Alliteration Admirer
about:
There are three things I truly believe in in this life that I imbue in all of my work as a designer and researcher: Beauty, Truth, and Responsibility. I believe in beauty in its many manifestations, and in the pursuit of beauty through genuine experiences. I believe in truth, and in its ability to remove the lacquer that covers an authentic vision, to allow full realization. I believe in the responsibility we each hold to improve both our own lives and the lives of others and those to come, to continue to create beautiful, truthful experiences.

All of that is to say, I read a lot of books and now I want my whole world to be as magical as those books are.

headline: ORISE Fellow - Oligonucleotide Mass Spectrometry at FDA I Analytical Chemistry & Pharmaceutical Biotechnology
about:
My current research at FDA focuses on developing and applying liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) based analytical methods for characterisation and quantitation of oligonucleotides and their impurities to support high-quality oligonucleotide drug development.

In my Ph.D. dissertation, I explored advanced oxidation processes and demonstrated their utility to the remediation of various problematic PFASs & organophosphorus compounds in water. I also synthesized titanium-oxide-based semiconductor materials that showed high photocatalytic performance in visible light. Before joining the Ph.D. program, I worked for years in a national research organization, investigated medicinal plants' pharmacological properties, and collaborated to develop infants' food formulas. I also developed/validated chromatography and mass spectrometry-based analytical methods and performed testing of metals/organics in water, environmental, food, and pharmaceutical samples. 

Technical skills:
‚ñ™ Mass spectrometry based Oligonucleotide characterization and impurities profiling
‚ñ™ Monitoring reaction kinetics, products identification and mechanistic investigation 
‚ñ™ Advanced oxidation processes, photocatalysis, and sonolysis  
‚ñ™ Multi-attribute method (MAM) development  
‚ñ™ Analytical method development and validation 
‚ñ™ Structure elucidation of small molecules and oligonucleotide
‚ñ™ Regulatory guidelines, including FDA, cGMP, GLP, ISO/IEC 17025, and EH&S

Analytical instrumentation: 
‚ñ™ Mass spectrometry (MS): LC-MS, LC-MS/MS, HRMS, Ion mobility MS system including Thermo Orbitrap Q-Exactive and Eclipse Tribrid, SCIEX QqQ API 5000, Waters Cyclic IMS, Thermo FAIMS
‚ñ™ HPLC system: Reversed phase & HILIC 
‚ñ™ GC system: GC-NPD & GC-MS 
‚ñ™ IC system: Dionex, Metrohm 761 Compact
‚ñ™ NMR: Bruker 600 MHz
‚ñ™ AAS/Fluorescence/UV-Vis spectroscopy 

‚ñ™ Technical software: Xcalibur, Chromeleon, BioPharma Finder, Promass, Skyline, Analyst, Compound Discoverer, LabSolutions, ChemStation, Mestrenova, and Topspin
‚ñ™ Data analysis: Python, Origin, Excel, and JMP

Basic troubleshooting: HPLC, LCMS, and GC

Soft skills:
‚ñ™ Strong communication & interpersonal skills
‚ñ™ Used to work independently and in a team 
‚ñ™ Able to learn/set in a new environment readily

about:
Biological engineer, creative communicator, enthusiastic teammate, strategist and problem solver. 

I am interested in the many facets of scientific practice and application, from development to dissemination. Over 7 years, I participated in 8 distinct biological research projects across 4 continents, collecting a wide array of technical and translational skills, all while obtaining a bachelor's degree from MIT and a master's degree from Stanford University. But seeing the large disconnect between scientific innovation and real world understanding, I pivoted my focus to creative communications and marketing at Ginkgo Bioworks, a rapidly growing synthetic biology company. 

Today, I seek to bridge the gap between scientific enterprise and the communities it seeks to serve by innovating short- and long-term infrastructures that can place the power for development and implementation of biotechnology into the hands of the wider community.

headline: College Student at Colorado State University-Pueblo

about: Born and raised in Brazil, I moved to the U.S. when I was 18 years-old fresh out of high school. Being an Au Pair helped me get acquainted with the language, culture and the American life style, prepping me for the road ahead. I then started my academic journey: an Associate‚Äôs degree in Business, then a Bachelor‚Äôs in Business and finally after a 3 year break, a Master‚Äôs in Business and Technology Management. During that time, I continued to work full time to put myself through school: I was a nanny for a few years, then started working for my in laws at their car shop and non-profit mission, and after that I did debt collection for a while. After I graduated with my Bachelor‚Äôs, I landed my first corporate job through the Carreer center at my school. Even though some may say this was the beginning of my professional journey, I think this was just a milestone in my professional journey. I have been working since I was 15 and to me work is not defined by my job title, but rather, it is the deep desire of accomplishing whatever task is at hand with my best possible effort. It doesn‚Äôt matter if I am a nanny or a business analyst, my drive to get the job done will always be what keeps me focused. I treasure hard work and believe that we all have what it takes within ourselves to achieve our dreams. Quitting is not in my vocabulary and impossible is just a matter of perspective. I may not have the most prestigious resume but what I do have is passion and that cannot be taught by any institution. It can only be learned in the school of life.

headline: Advanced Concept Engineer at L3Harris Technologies
about:
I am a tool builder, and I have been from the very outset of my career. I came out of school with a degree in architectural engineering, and immediately went to work for a company producing software tools for the design and analysis of architectural lighting systems. Since those early days, I have steadily honed my craft to produce software of uncompromising accuracy, speed, and directness of usability.

The best tools are built by those who use tools. My early work in non-imaging optical analysis software was born of my work in designing life-critical lighting systems for the operating table. Today, I spend hundreds of hours a year engaged in digital astrophotography. This hobby has yielded dozens of techniques, algorithms, and usability ideas that feed my professional work of building sophisticated analytics to extract insight from geospatial imagery and related data.

As my career has matured, I have developed the skill of operating at higher levels of abstraction, evolving from software engineer to software architect. Today, my favorite challenges usually center on taking on a complex problem, identifying big picture patterns, and organizing an effective blend of new and existing technology to meet the challenge.  I have a gift for deconstructing and explaining complex problems clearly, but I also still enjoy getting down to the ‚Äúnitty-gritty‚Äù details to solve those problems.  

When I‚Äôm not building software or processing astrophotography images, I enjoy travelling, mountaineering here in Colorado, listening to and learning about music, and going on long bike rides.
job_title: Advanced Concept Engineer, Space and Airborne Systems

about:
I am an entry-level User Researcher and Experience Designer with a Master‚Äôs in Library and Information Science who aims to use design and technology to create equitable and impactful products. 

My education in Information Science challenged me to critically think about the ways information is presented and categorized which equips me with the unique understanding and skill when improving a product‚Äôs information architecture. 

Working with Humans of User Experience, I have conducted qualitative and quantitative user research, collaborated with a team of designers and researchers to develop solutions, and communicate findings and solutions to stakeholders.

In April 2021, I began a community organization, La Puente Mini Makers, that focuses on providing kids in my community with free STEM and art kits to complete at home during the COVID-19 pandemic. In collaboration with parents, educators, and small businesses who host La Puente Mini Maker kits, I research, curate, and put together STEM and art-based kits to encourage kids to learn, create, and explore new ideas, while encouraging families to support small businesses in our community. In just a few months, I put together over 1,500 kits for kids to take home and have expanded from three small businesses hosting kits to five. From starting La Puente Mini Makers, I have learned the importance of empathy and compassion that are invaluable in designing experiences that are meaningful, inclusive, delightful, efficient, and equitable for users.

Currently, I am seeking a remote or on-site Experience Designer position with an established UX team that will provide mentorship and the opportunity to use my past experiences, while also enhancing my skill set.

headline: Manufacturing Engineer at Xos Trucks
about:
As an Industrial and Mechanical Engineer, I draw on a track record of facilitating vehicle design improvements for automotive companies. I achieve this by leveraging my engineering expertise, identifying faults, and utilizing rootcause analysis techniques. Additionally, I am adept at using cutting-edge tools and engineering design and analysis skills.
Most recently, for instance, as a Vehicle Evaluator at Roush, I exceeded my goal to find 3 faults per vehicle. I achieved this by carefully evaluating vehicle performance, conducting secondary research to keep common vehicle issues in mind, and overexerting the vehicle. My feedback and fault identification spurred critical quality improvements for Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) prototype vehicles. Moreover, I also benchmarked vehicles for product validation and improvement here.

I am passionate about vehicle safety and design improvements. During my master‚Äôs in industrial engineering, I undertook a project to recommend product improvements for an airbag design. I approached this project using the Six Sigma Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control (DMAIC) tool and quickly identified the propellant used for airbag deployment as the cause of product degradation. then recommended two viable solutions‚Äîa new and improved, tubular airbag design as well as an alternative material for the propellant.

My interest in vehicles and taking on new challenges extends to creating go-karts and racing cars and participating in competitions. I was part of a team that ranked in the top 60 out of 200 teams for a Formula SAE SUPRA event. For this project, I undertook the responsibility to resolve powertrain mounting issues. I also helped with the design and fabrication of the chassis. I also co-built a single-passenger electric go-kart operated via battery for the Eco-Kart Series.

If you are interested in working with someone who identifies and fixes engineering issues through industrial and mechanical testing and design strategies, I can be reached via email: abdulmuqeeth631@gmail.com

headline: Procurement Engineer (E-CAT) at IBM
about:
Every moment of your daily routines has an impact on who you are. Whether you realize it or not everyone faces challenges daily and how each person faces these challenges is what makes a person unique. I see engineering the same way, a challenge that someone needs to solve and that is the reason I found myself loving engineering. The word ‚ÄúEngineering‚Äù seems complicated and difficult to comprehend to most; however, for me, I see it as a means of expressing my creativity to the problem and the solution is the art.

College is similar in a way, we are given a set of problems from our professors to find our creativity to the problem and how each student approach the problem was different. These differences could lead to innovations that could greatly impact the world.

For my first professional project, I was allowed to develop an alternative to Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). This project was conducted with a ground of using equipment that was available to us at the time. After a couple of months of design work, the prototype was complete. The Prototype was not at all what the client had hope for; nonetheless, the client was ecstatic with how it functions which had provided a new approach to the problem and from there a new potential to the finished product. This is what keeps me going, an endless cycle that will continuously create innovation.

The most important thing that school has taught me is that education is a means to an end, we must always pursue what each value as important. Most importantly, in my life, I see that I majored in mechanical and electrical engineering to broaden my creativity to approach the problem and this will help me become someone who is inspiring.

headline: Customer Care presso DIRA
Inspirational Speaker - Employee retention, Blindspots, Vision
about:
Embrace diversity. Build high-performance teams by leading people that are different from you. 

When's the last time you had a review and you walked out concentrating on the negative and not the positive? If you could just improve in that one area, I'd be a rock star! 

What if you flipped that and looked at what you could improve in your strong areas? 

I love to help people see things that they should be seeing. This allows them to unlock their full potential and begin to live their life on purpose.

My mission is to help people embrace their own personal blindness to achieve a greater vision. The process takes people from a point of blindness, into sight, and toward a greater vision.   

I was born and raised in Northwest Ohio as the son of a tomato farmer and the youngest of 10 kids. In 1977, at the age of 10, I was diagnosed with hydrocephalus, a brain malformation. Over the course of the next 33 years I experienced several instances of medical issues resulting from this diagnosis. 

On March 4th of 2011, I woke up blind. 

Only brain surgery and multiple eye surgeries have allowed a portion of my sight to return.

Since then, I have become an author of the semi-autobiography book "Sometimes It DOES Take a Brain Surgeon".

Following surgery, I've realized that I have blind spots that have nothing to do with my vision. My speaking engagements have allowed me to help other people see and eliminate their blind spots, with the help of a letter from my daughter. Participants in my program have also embraced what makes them unique as they have "winked with Wagner". Lastly their vision, preferred future, has come into clear focus. 

I use my experiences to help the audience to improve their sales, leadership, and lives by teaching them how to see what they're missing as a result of their own blindness. 

My unique process takes people from Blindness to Sight to Vision. This can be found in my book, which you can find here. https://www.aradicalvision.com/store/
		
Accomplishments:
* Published author - 2017
* Professional Member of the National Speakers Association

Brian Wagner

headline: Director at Head and Neck Pain Center
about:
The Head and Neck Pain Center is dedicated 100% to nonsurgical, non-drug treatment of TMJ problems which can include headaches, neck pain, back pain, earaches, jaw pain, facial pain, jaw joint noises and vertigo. Many of these symptoms are confused with Migraines. 

The Center's Director, Dr. A Richard Goldman, is the author of "TMJ Syndrome: The Overlooked Diagnosis", as well as many scientific articles. He has also taught his concepts throughout the U.S.

headline: Assistant Teacher at MAAC (MAAC Project)
about:
I am a passionate and creative driven early childhood teacher, currently working as an Assistant Teacher under MAAC Project. I've worked in early childhood education for 14 years and hope to continue my career in early childhood education until I retire. 

My interest in early childhood education first stemmed from my own educational experience. As a child, I was always encouraged to value my education and to never lose my curiosity to learn more about the world around me. That curiosity then helped me realize how important a child's education is in the early phases of life, which is why I am now a pre-school teacher. My teaching method also stems from this source of curiosity. At the early stages of childhood, all children are extremely curious about the world around them. I then foster that curiosity and use auditory, visual and linguistic teaching methods to help the child further develop the necessary skills they'll need in life and their educational journeys.

I am committed to my students and their families and hope to provide a safe and peaceful environment for them to learn and grow together.

headline: Research Scientist at zeroK NanoTech
about:
I am presently a Postdoctoral Fellow working at the startup company zeroK NanoTech.  My current research is on the application of atomic physics and laser cooling techniques to the development of a cold ion source for focused ion beam (FIB) instruments.  We are collaborating with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Center for Nanoscale Science and Technology (CNST) on this project.  My appointment at zeroK NanoTech is enabled by the Small Business Postdoctoral Research Diversity Fellowship from the American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE); this is an NSF-supported fellowship.

In my other recent research I have studied rubidium atoms in highly excited electronic states, known as Rydberg states.  In early 2014 I used their sensitivity to electromagnetic fields to develop an atom-based sensing technique for RF and mm-wave electric fields.  This work was in collaboration with researchers at NIST, Boulder.  In my Ph.D. thesis work I studied the interactions between Rydberg atoms.  These are relevant to quantum information processing, and also play a role in energy transfer in atomic gases.

headline: Professor | Chair MBA Program | Consultant | Investor
about:
I am an academic, consultant, and administrator. My academic work has recently focused on how to reform state-owned enterprises and on multinational entry strategies into emerging markets. I have also done extensive MBA and executive education teaching on strategy and entrepreneurship in emerging markets and state-owned enterprise reform. I consult or have acted as a consultant for the OECD, The World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank, and a variety of multinational firms. I have a variety of academic papers and books on corporate governance and governance in state-owned firms.

As an instructor, I lecture and run executive programs in the United States, Brazil, Mexico, Colombia, Uruguay, Chile, etc. I am also frequently a keynote  speaker at business meetings, on topics that range from economic scenarios and their impact for businesses (e.g., the Harvard Business Review Scenarios Conference in Brazil) to more tailor-made presentations for industry-peak associations (e.g., the Association of Retailers of Brazil) or corporate boards (e.g., Henkel, Femsa, etc.). 

I also enjoy being a manager of academic programs. At Harvard Business School I was the chair of their Latin America Advisory Board until early 2014, managing relations with alumni and board members, and leading the efforts of their regional research centers in Brazil, Argentina and Mexico. At the International Business School, Brandeis University, I am the Director of the Latin America Initiative and the Brazil Initiative. Thus, I also manage relations with alumni and donors in Latin America, I organize academic programs on campus and academic trips to the region, and, I coordinate the relationship the school has with students and universities in the region. Finally, I am or have been on the board of non-profit education institutions, such as business schools, and more recently at LASPAU, an organization that helps place Latin American students in top programs in the United States.

headline: Ph.C., Doctoral Candidate
about:
My name is Alan-Michael Weatherford (preferably AM), and I am an interdisciplinary researcher, critical pedagogue, and doctoral candidate at the University of Washington‚ÄîSeattle. 

While my home department was Comparative Literature, Cinema and Media (CLCM), I frequently teach in other departments, such as the French and Italian as well as Spanish and Portuguese. In the past few years, I have taught in and cross-listed my courses with the Comparative History of Ideas Department (CHID). I also work closely with the 501 c(3) non-profit organization, University Beyond Bars (UBB), providing educational opportunities at the Monroe Correctional Complex in classroom, workshop, and cultural lectures and series formats. 

I'm currently in the final stages of writing my dissertation and completing my PhD program. My project, (Neo)Liberal Logics of Caribbean Sex Tourism, is an interdisciplinary and multilingual study of various representations of sex workers in Caribbean cultural production. By focusing on the ways that sex workers are rendered in literary and filmic media, I illuminate a variety of epistemic practices, characterized as sometimes violent and at other times asserting autonomy that subtend racial capitalism. Divided into two major parts, the first section investigates the modes of violence as well as resistance under liberal formations in Jamaica and Haiti. The latter analyzes those modes under neoliberal formations in the Dominican Republic and Cuba. Altogether, I provide a genealogical account from 1970 into the early 2000s of U.S. imperial or transnational capitalist expansion into the Caribbean under the guise of development and economic restructuring for democratic ends.

In the 2018-2019 school yeah, I taught with the Comparative History of Ideas Department (CHID) through their Collaborative Learning and Interdisciplinary Pedagogy Fellowship (CLIP). Together with a colleague in English, Caleb Knapp, we designed and taught a 5-course series related to the theme of Critical Justice Studies. I also teach and volunteer in the Monroe Correctional Facility with the amazing non-profit organization, University Beyond Bars.

headline: Registered Nurse at Franciscan Health
Sr. Building Envelope Consultant at Sullivan Engineering, A Rimkus Company
about:
I remember the first book my dad bought me. It was written in Indonesian and literally translated to ‚ÄúTell Me Why‚Äù.  The book contained simple explanations to questions that children ask, such as ‚ÄúWhy is the ocean so salty‚Äù, or ‚ÄúWhat is the difference between a fruit and a vegetable‚Äù.  Having this book read to me, ignited a sense of curiosity in me since I was little which has never died since.

Now how do I harness this curiosity?  I decided to focus my career in forensics engineering! Interweaving it with my interest in buildings and architecture, I specialise in understanding the root causes and mechanisms that lead to the failures of components and/or systems in the built environment.

Throughout my career, I have inspected over 300 distinct buildings, ranging from single-storey residential dwellings in the outback, to one of the highest residential apartment building in Australia.

The types of issues that I have diagnosed and repaired, includes the following (to name a few):

	- Interior and exterior waterproofing membranes
	- Combustible cladding
	- Building movements induced by reactive clay soils
	- Concrete reinforcement spalling 
	- Glazing elements
	- Lightweight cladding
	- Parking garages

I am not your regular engineer.  I'm a very visual person and love utilising sketches and diagrams to depict my ideas.  This includes hand-drawn details to computer models for clients and contractors alike.  I am naturally outgoing and have a high level of personal energy!  I love coordination, sharing experiences, and knowledge with others around me which makes me thrive in teams.   

When I am not crawling under buildings or hanging out the side of skyscrapers, I enjoy practicing and competing in Brazilian Jiu Jitsu, cooking, and reading.

I love a good chat - so don't hesitate to reach out.

headline: Credit Consultant: Non-Profit Donations Accepted
about:
Without paying large amounts of money, we encourage our customers to donate a minimal amount through the Mobile Giving Foundation, utilizing experience in the collections industry, working directly with consumers, retailers, lawyers, and debt consolidation companies and have developed an understanding of many different angles and approaches used to improve credit, as well as what is most effective.   Put your money to someone who is need and allow us to service your best interest with quality service.
 
      Information is used to generate a credit score to measure a person's credibility.  Since credit scores only calculate information reported, two consumers can have completely different credit scores, even if their financial situations are very similar, depending on how finances are managed.  Understanding how credit is calculated, allows an individual to organize their finances into a structure that enhances their ability to achieve A + credit, with out improving there financial situation.
     A + Credit Acquirer‚Äôs services are strictly customized according to each customer‚Äôs specific needs related to their financial situation.  A + Credit Acquirer will provide the fastest way to acquire A + credit regardless of the situation. 

 This is accomplished by analyzing multiple factors related to the following types of Services:
Impact of each account on your credit based on:
   Type of account
   Date account was opened
   Date account was last paid
   Amounts owing
   Ownership of debt
   Organize what debts should be paid
   Organize what debts should not be paid
   Prioritize order of importance to pay debts needing paid
   Establishment of credit
   Rebuilding credit
   Obtaining ways to build credit when you have bad credit
   Negotiations
   Deletions

headline: Advancing Technology from its Scientific Roots
about:
I am an experimental physics Ph.D. student the University of California, Santa Barbara.  My research interests dominantly lie in quantum transport and terahertz/mm-wave excitations of 2D quantum materials, primarily graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides. My unique and extensive academic and industrial background in electrical engineering, microwave and terahertz electromagnetics, and solid state electronic devices allows to me push the capabilities of modern measurements into the next age. 

I am also a development engineer at Lake Shore Cryotronics. I seek to develop and use new techniques and technologies to both simplify and further scientific endeavors at the global scale. I am interested in mixing raw physics and engineering with modern electronic instruments to turn standalone tools into platforms for probing cutting-edge physics. 

My personal website: http://web.physics.ucsb.edu/~ampotts/

headline: Process Engineer | Research & Development | Engineering Design & Simulations | Catalyst Synthesis | Process Optimization
about:
I am a professional engineer and a catalyst researcher with background in oil and gas business. I have 16+ years combined experience in process design and simulation, gas plant troubleshooting and novel catalyst development. 

My area of expertise include:

- Core discipline of process engineering duties, such as process design studies, developing process flow diagram, process simulation, equipment sizing and selection, detailed calculations, reviewing vendors' design, applicable codes and standards

-Heterogeneous catalysis related to diesel hydrotreating, methane-steam reforming, methanol-steam reforming and water gas shift reactions.

-Capable of conducting independent, systematic and thorough catalyst synthesis, chemical process research and analysis.

I also have years of hands-on experience with micro reactor design, test stand construction, X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), BET surface area analysis, thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis (TGA), gas chromatography (GC), mass spectrometry (MS), and chemisorption.

headline: Medical Information and Scientific Communications at Acadia Pharmaceuticals Inc.
about:
Lead Medical Affairs Strategist for our Ironwood products. Additional experience leading and managing medical affairs and medical information departments. As the Medical Strategist I am responsible for the life cycle management of key deliverables for Medical Scientific Affairs, with a focus on improving the digital presence and impact of our MSA team. Some pertinent responsibilities include the development of a product specific medical affairs strategies, a new CRM for MSLs and KOL engagement, the implementation of a grant management systems (CME, IIT sponsorships) and the development of tools that allow KOLs streamlined access to medical education/information. Additional responsibilities include the development of SOPs, lead medical reviewer for MLR or promotional material review, congress strategy/planning, the maintenance of standard response letters and FAQs, responding to escalated cases, contributing to brand planning and medical affairs strategy. My previous roles have included leading the medical review for promotional and medical materials, selection and implementation of Medical Information databases, training relevant employees on specific clinical/medical information/compliance topics, collection/reporting of adverse events/product complaints and contributing the the strategic development plans for the company.
As a Post-Doctoral Research Fellow I was able to conduct in vitro, in-vivo and clinical research in the critical care and nephrology/dialysis settings through grants funded by pharmaceutical companies. Through collaboration with various healthcare professionals and academic researchers we identified and tried to fill the void pertaining to proper medication use in patients with kidney injury. Additionally, I was responsible for the creation of lectures, development and submission of grants and manuscripts, presenting data a key congresses/conferences and mentoring pharmacy students. 
I have a experience in the following: Medical Information, Medical Writing, Clinical Research, Pharmacy Practice, Patient Education, Medicine, Medical Affairs, Pharmacovigilance, Training and Clinical Trials.
